adjective.description: Of a more excellent or effective type or quality.
examples: the new facilities were far better
I'm better at algebra than Alice

adjective.description: Partly or fully recovered from illness, injury, or mental stress; less unwell.
examples: we'll feel a lot better after a decent night's sleep
Johnny could do better if he tried
instruments are generally better made these days

noun.description: The better one; that which is better.
examples: the Natural History Museum book is by far the better of the two

noun.description: One's superiors in social class or ability.
examples: amusing themselves by imitating their betters

verb.description: Improve on or surpass (an existing or previous level or achievement)
examples: bettering his previous time by ten minutes

phrases: the sooner we're off the better
the more people there the better
Mr Ancram said: We live in an age of computerisation and the earlier you can learn the skills the better, even for very young children.
If anything, the sketchier the questions the better.
Automatic promotion is still on the cards and the more help the team has from the terraces the better.
origin: Old English betera (adjective), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch beter and German besser, also to best.
